The German occupation 
forces wipe out the biggest 
part of the city’s Jewish 
population by sending them to 
concentration camps.
 1978:	
A mighty earthquake 
occurs on June 20th reaching 
6.5 on the Richter scale. 
Severe damages are inflicted 
on the town, resulting in the 
death of 49 people.
 1997:	
Thessaloniki becomes the 
“European Capital of Culture”.
 2014:	
The city is named the 
“European Youth Capital”.', '99
GASTRONOMY AND WINES
GASTRONOMY AND WINES
Thessaloniki has a great 
culinary tradition which has 
become an intrinsic part  
of the character and mentality  
of the locals. The city’s multi-
cultural character across the 
ages has added an indelible 
stamp on its traditional cuisine 
which includes Byzantine, 
Christian, Ottoman influences 
and elements contributed by 
the large numbers of Minor 
Asia refugees who flowed in 
the town during the 1920s, 
and also Jewish and western 
European influences, thus 
creating unique culinary 
combinations. Downtown (see 
p. 15-41), in Ano Poli (see p. 
42 - 49) and in the seaside 
suburbs and city outskirts (see 
p. 63 - 69), the traditional 
tavernas, ouzo restaurants and 
luxury restaurants highlight the 
local traditional gastronomy 
often creatively mixing it with 
gourmet tastes. 
Thessaloniki’s gastronomy 
can boast some pretty 
impressive delicacies 
[mezedes] such as gyro [slices 
of meat roasted on a spit] and 
souvlaki, patsa, a variety of 
soup, pies, Anatolian dishes 
(tzigerosarmades, giaprakia, 
gardoumpes, kebab etc), 
lake and sea fish, seafood 
delicacies (mussel pilaf, 
saganaki with shrimps, stuffed 
calamari etc).', 'It is divided in 
three sections (cold, tepid 
and hot areas) and there is 
also a vaulted tank for heating 
water. It is widely known as the 
Paradise Baths and it went by 
that name until 1968. Right next 
to it there is a roman platform 
that is indicative of the ground 
level 2000 years ago.
1.6  Roman (Ancient) Forum
During the roman period, 
this 2-hectare area used to be 
the social and religious centre 
of the city. Construction was 
completed in two phases  
(in the mid-2nd and mid-  
3rd centuries AD) and it was 
gradually abandoned after the 
7th century. The NW section 
of the archaeological site is 
covered by a large rectangular 
square [Α] with traces of 
marble paving. In the S section 
of the square lies the largest 
part of the double underground 
Cryptoporticus [covered 
passageway] [Β] which was 
most probably used as a public 
storehouse.']
reference_contexts:
['Late 19th c.:	
A railway connection is 
established with Europe and 
Constantinople. Infrastructure 
gets streamlined and 
Thessaloniki acquires the feel 
of a cosmopolitan European 
city. The Greeks become at 
this point in time the largest 
part of the population.
 ']
response:
Several factors contributed to the Greeks becoming the largest part of the population in Thessaloniki during the late 19th century. 

Firstly, the establishment of a railway connection with Europe and Constantinople significantly enhanced trade and mobility, attracting more Greeks to the city. This infrastructure development facilitated economic growth and made Thessaloniki a cosmopolitan hub, drawing in individuals seeking better opportunities.

Secondly, the city's transformation into a large trade center during the 16th to 18th centuries laid the groundwork for a diverse population. The harmonious coexistence of various ethnic and religious communities created an environment conducive to migration and settlement, particularly for Greeks who were increasingly drawn to urban centers for economic prospects.

Additionally, the late 19th century saw a rise in national consciousness among Greeks, spurred by the broader movements for independence and national identity in the region. This cultural revival encouraged many Greeks from rural areas and other regions to migrate to Thessaloniki, seeking to be part of a burgeoning urban identity that resonated with their national aspirations.

Moreover, the demographic shifts were influenced by the socio-political climate of the time. As the Ottoman Empire began to decline, many Greeks felt a sense of urgency to establish a stronger presence in key cities like Thessaloniki, which was historically significant to Greek heritage.

Lastly, the influx of Greek refugees from Asia Minor, particularly after the Asia Minor Catastrophe in the early 20th century, further solidified the Greek demographic majority in Thessaloniki. This migration not only increased the Greek population but also enriched the city's cultural tapestry, blending various culinary and social traditions that continue to define Thessaloniki today.

In summary, the combination of economic opportunities, national revival, demographic shifts, and historical migrations played a crucial role in making Greeks the largest part of Thessaloniki's population by the late 19th century.
reference: The establishment of a railway connection with Europe and Constantinople, along with streamlined infrastructure, contributed to the Greeks becoming the largest part of the population in Thessaloniki during the late 19th century.

ANCIENT PELLA
Inhabited since the Late 
Helladic period, the area 
flourished when Archelaos,  
the Macedon king, moved  
the capital of the Macedonian 
state from Aiges (Vergina) to 
Pella (late 5th – early 4th c. BC). 
The then seaside town grew 
larger during the reign of King 
Philip II (his son, Alexander 
the Great, was born here) 
and grew even larger later 
during the rule of Cassander. 
By the mid-2nd century BC it 
had evolved into the greatest 
political, financial and cultural 
centre among the Hellenic City 
States. In 168 BC when the 
Macedonians were defeated in 
the battle of Pydna, Pella was 
conquered by the Romans. 
It gradually declined and got 
eventually deserted in the 1st 
century BC. Among the finds 
of the greatest value are the 
exquisite mosaic floors in the 
buildings, which manifest the 
high standard of living enjoyed 
by the residents.

response:
The lion hunting scene depicted in the Pella Archaeological Museum is a significant representation of ancient Macedonian culture and artistry, dating back to between 325-200 BC. This mosaic, showcasing a dynamic and dramatic moment of a lion hunt, reflects not only the artistic skills of the period but also the cultural values and social practices of the Macedonian elite.

Hunting, particularly of lions, was often associated with power, bravery, and nobility in ancient societies. It symbolized the strength and prowess of the individual, often linked to the ideals of heroism and the warrior ethos prevalent in Macedonian culture. The depiction of such scenes in art served to reinforce the status of the elite, showcasing their connection to the heroic past and their dominance over nature.

Moreover, the lion hunting scene can be interpreted as a metaphor for the struggles and triumphs of the Macedonian people during a time of significant political and military developments, particularly under the reign of influential figures like Philip II and his son, Alexander the Great. This period marked the rise of Macedonia as a powerful state in the ancient world, and the art produced during this time often celebrated these themes of conquest and valor.

Visiting the Pella Archaeological Museum provides an opportunity to engage with these historical narratives, offering insights into the lives of the ancient Macedonians and their artistic expressions. The museum houses other significant artifacts that further illustrate the high standard of living and cultural sophistication of the time, making it a must-see for anyone interested in the rich history of Greece.
reference: The lion hunting scene depicted in the Pella Archaeological Museum holds historical significance as it represents art from the period of 325-200 BC, showcasing cultural and artistic achievements of that era.

response:
The neolithic settlement mentioned in the context of Hellenic history is significant for several reasons. Firstly, it represents one of the earliest forms of organized human habitation in the region, showcasing the transition from nomadic lifestyles to settled agricultural communities. This shift is crucial in understanding the development of social structures, trade, and cultural practices in ancient Greece.

The settlement is noted for its size, being considered the largest in the Hellenic area, which indicates a thriving community that likely engaged in various economic activities, including farming and trade. The presence of a cemetery and early-Christian basilicas within the site further highlights the continuity of human activity and the evolution of religious practices over time. This layering of history provides valuable insights into the cultural and spiritual life of the inhabitants.

Moreover, the archaeological findings, including tools and remnants of daily life, contribute to our understanding of the technological advancements and lifestyle of the people during the Neolithic period. Such discoveries help historians and archaeologists piece together the narrative of human development in Greece, illustrating how these early societies laid the groundwork for the later, more complex civilizations that followed, such as the Hellenistic and Classical periods.

In summary, the neolithic settlement is significant not only for its size and the artifacts found but also for its role in the broader context of Hellenic history. It serves as a testament to the early human endeavor in the region, marking a pivotal point in the evolution of Greek civilization and its cultural heritage. Exploring such sites can provide a deeper appreciation of Greece's rich historical tapestry, making it an essential aspect of any visit to the area.
reference: The neolithic settlement is significant in Hellenic history as it is considered the largest in the Hellenic area, alongside a cemetery and early-Christian basilicas, highlighting the region's historical and cultural importance.

this point in time the largest 
part of the population.
 1890:	
Fire incinerates a considerable 
part of the town’s seafront 
zone.
 1912:	
During the 1st Balkan War, 
the Greek army seizes the 
town on October 26th; after 
five centuries of ottoman 
occupation, Thessaloniki 
becomes part of Greece.
 1916:	
Following a clash with 
King Constantine, Eleftherios 
Venizelos forms the 
temporary “National Defence 
Government” in Thessaloniki, 
which remained there for 
several months.
 1917:	
The biggest part of the 
town is destroyed by a fire 
that breaks out on August 
18th and lasts for 32 hours.']

The mention of over 13,000 beds in Thessaloniki's hotel infrastructure highlights the city's capacity to accommodate a diverse range of travelers, particularly during peak tourist seasons like summer. This significant number indicates a well-developed hospitality sector that caters to various budgets and preferences, making it an attractive destination for leisure travelers.

For a solo traveler seeking budget-friendly options, the availability of numerous establishments ensures that there are choices that align with different financial constraints. This variety allows visitors to find suitable accommodations without compromising on comfort or quality, which is essential for a pleasant stay.

Moreover, the modern and high-standard infrastructure of these hotels enhances the overall travel experience. Travelers can expect amenities that cater to their needs, such as free Wi-Fi, breakfast options, and convenient locations near popular attractions. This is particularly beneficial for those interested in sightseeing, as it allows easy access to key landmarks and Instagrammable spots around the city.

The presence of a robust hotel infrastructure also fosters opportunities for local interaction. Many hotels organize tours, cultural experiences, or events that encourage guests to engage with the local community, enriching their travel experience. This aligns well with the desire to meet locals and immerse oneself in the culture.

In summary, the 13,000 beds capacity signifies Thessaloniki's readiness to welcome a large influx of visitors, providing a range of accommodation options that cater to budget-conscious travelers. This infrastructure not only supports leisure activities but also enhances the potential for cultural exchange and memorable experiences during a weekend stay.

ANCIENT PELLA
Inhabited since the Late 
Helladic period, the area 
flourished when Archelaos,  
the Macedon king, moved  
the capital of the Macedonian 
state from Aiges (Vergina) to 
Pella (late 5th – early 4th c. BC). 
The then seaside town grew 
larger during the reign of King 
Philip II (his son, Alexander 
the Great, was born here) 
and grew even larger later 
during the rule of Cassander. 
By the mid-2nd century BC it 
had evolved into the greatest 
political, financial and cultural 
centre among the Hellenic City 
States. In 168 BC when the 
Macedonians were defeated in 
the battle of Pydna, Pella was 
conquered by the Romans. 
It gradually declined and got 
eventually deserted in the 1st 
century BC. Among the finds 
of the greatest value are the 
exquisite mosaic floors in the 
buildings, which manifest the 
high standard of living enjoyed 
by the residents.

response:
Nea Apollonia, located on the south side of Lake Volvi, holds significant historical importance as it was once the site of a prominent Macedonian town during the 5th century BC. This area was known for its mineral springs, which were believed to have therapeutic properties, particularly for treating various ailments such as neuropathy, rheumatism, arthritis, and skin conditions. The springs, with temperatures reaching 49-50°C, flow into Lake Volvi, enhancing the region's appeal as a health and wellness destination.

In addition to its natural resources, Nea Apollonia is historically notable for its connection to the ancient Macedonian civilization. The town's proximity to Thessaloniki and other archaeological sites makes it an ideal spot for visitors interested in exploring the rich history of Macedonia. The nearby Info Centre for the Koroneia-Volvi Wetlands provides insights into the local ecosystem and the historical significance of the wetlands, showcasing the diverse species that inhabit the area.

As a first-time visitor, you can appreciate the blend of history and nature in Nea Apollonia. The remnants of the ancient town, coupled with modern amenities such as hotels and a health center, create a unique experience that allows for both relaxation and exploration. The town's historical context, combined with its natural beauty, makes it an excellent destination for sightseeing and engaging with local culture. 

Overall, Nea Apollonia serves as a reminder of the region's ancient past while offering contemporary comforts, making it a worthwhile stop on your journey through Macedonia.
reference: Nea Apollonia holds historical significance as an important Macedonian town that existed in the 5th century BC.
